title: Problem Overview
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #168** about {n, 2n, 3n}-free sets. Let F(N) be the maximum size of a subset of {1,...,N} avoiding all such triples. What is the limiting density lim F(N)/N?
mathContext: Graham-Spencer-Witsenhausen (1977) proved the limit exists. The limit ≈ 0.5564 involves 3-smooth numbers (2^a · 3^b). Erdős asked whether this limit is irrational—still open.

title: Contains Triple
content: **ContainsTriple A** means A contains some {n, 2n, 3n} where n ≥ 1. This is a 'multiplicative' arithmetic progression with common ratio 2.
mathContext: ContainsTriple A := ∃ n ≥ 1, n ∈ A ∧ 2*n ∈ A ∧ 3*n ∈ A. Note this is different from additive APs like {n, n+d, n+2d}.

title: Triple-Free Sets
content: **IsTripleFree A** means A contains NO {n, 2n, 3n} triple. This is the negation of ContainsTriple.
mathContext: IsTripleFree A := ¬ContainsTriple A. The goal is to find the largest such sets within {1,...,N}.

title: The Function F(N)
content: **F(N)** is the maximum cardinality of a triple-free subset of {1,...,N}. This is defined as a supremum over all valid sets.
mathContext: F N := sSup { k | ∃ A ⊆ Icc 1 N, IsTripleFree A ∧ A.card = k }. The noncomputable definition uses sSup for the maximum.

title: Density Bounded
content: **Proved**: The density F(N)/N is always between 0 and 1. This is trivial since F(N) ≤ N.
mathContext: density_bounded : 0 ≤ F(N)/N ≤ 1. The proof uses positivity and that any subset has cardinality at most N.

title: Monotonicity
content: **Proved**: F is monotone: F(N) ≤ F(N+1). Any triple-free subset of {1,...,N} is also a subset of {1,...,N+1}.
mathContext: F_monotone : F N ≤ F (N + 1). The proof uses that subsets of {1,...,N} inject into subsets of {1,...,N+1}.

title: 3-Smooth Numbers
content: The **3-smooth numbers** are integers of the form 2^a · 3^b for a, b ≥ 0. These are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9, 12, 16, 18, 24, ...
mathContext: ThreeSmooth := { n | ∃ a b : ℕ, n = 2^a * 3^b }. The limit formula involves summing 1/d_k over these numbers.

title: GSW Limit Theorem
content: **Graham-Spencer-Witsenhausen (1977)**: The limit lim_{N→∞} F(N)/N exists. This is axiomatized since the proof requires deep analysis.
mathContext: axiom gsw_limit_exists : ∃ L, Tendsto (F N / N) atTop (nhds L). The limit is computed to be ≈ 0.5564.

title: Simple Lower Bound
content: **Proved**: F(N) ≥ 2N/3 - 1. This follows from removing all multiples of 3 from {1,...,N}—the remaining set is triple-free.
mathContext: simple_lower_bound : F(N) ≥ 2N/3 - 1. If we exclude {3, 6, 9, ...}, no {n, 2n, 3n} triple can exist since 3n would always be missing.

title: Irrationality Question
content: **Open Problem**: Is the limit lim F(N)/N irrational? Erdős posed this question but it remains unsolved.
mathContext: IrrationalityQuestion := Irrational limitDensity. The theorem irrationality_open just states it's either true or false (classical logic).

title: Small Examples
content: We verify: {1, 2} is triple-free (no room for 3n), and {1, 2, 3} contains the triple {1, 2, 3} since 1, 2·1=2, 3·1=3 are all present.
mathContext: The examples use explicit case analysis with omega tactic to verify membership and non-membership.
